items.title: Development server autoreload on included modules changes
items.body: Should automatic reload work on changes in included modules under Django's development server?

items.title: Remove flake8-pytest
items.body:
@lk-geimfari do you have the time to remove `flake8-pytest` from our dev dependencies?
Related: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/issues/1221

items.title: Include an absolute path file.
items.body:
I've been checking the code and it doesn't seem possible to include a file with absolute path. Is there any alternative in this regard ?

The code always gathers the file paths relative to the settings it calls include.

```pattern = os.path.join(conf_path, conf_file)```

items.title: Python 3.8 support
items.body:
Does it support `Python 3.8`? If it does, why not add `3.8` to Travis's config? Or, maybe because of `wemake-style-guide`?

I can work on it if you think that we need this. Thanks.

items.title: Fix Django version constrains in .travis.yml
items.body:
Hi @sobolevn!

I use `django-split-settings` for a long time and find it very useful and it is the one of the several packages I've install every time when creating a new Django project. Thank you!

I've found a small bug in your `.travis.yml`. You use `pip` to install different Django versions to run tests in multiple environments. But tilde requirements in `poetry` and `pip` are differs from each other. In `poetry` version constraint `~2.1` means `>=2.1.0 <2.2.0` whereas in `pip` it is `>=2.1 <3.0.0`. Thus you can found that tests for Django 2.1 actually [run on 2.2](https://travis-ci.org/sobolevn/django-split-settings/jobs/600588915#L359).

One of the solution of this issue I propose in PR.

items.title: Relative imports do not work
items.body:
**File structure:**
```
config/
      settings/
            components/
                  __init__.py
                  base.py
            environments/
                  __init__.py
                  development.py
            __init__.py
```

**`config/settings/__init__.py`**
```python3
import environ
from split_settings.tools import include


env = environ.Env()

DJANGO_ENV = env('DJANGO_ENV', default='development')

base_settings = (
    'components/base.py',
    'environments/{0}.py'.format(DJANGO_ENV),
)

include(*base_settings)
```

**`config/settings/environments/development.py`**
```python3
from ..components.base import INSTALLED_APPS, LOGGING, MIDDLEWARE

# code
```

And I get the error:
```
from ..components.base import INSTALLED_APPS, LOGGING, MIDDLEWARE
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'config.components'
```

But the absolute import works:
```python3
from config.settings.components.base import INSTALLED_APPS, LOGGING, MIDDLEWARE

# code
```

items.title: Unresolved Libraries in Templates - PyCharm & Django 2.2
items.body:
Following the Tutorial and creating the settings package or settings.py file and importing INSTALLED_APPS causes PyCharm to complain about unresolved libraries in HTML file.

ex: {% load staticfiles %} will give an unresolved library error

This Could be a PyCharm Issue as, as everything still runs without issue with "runserver" command.

items.title: How correctly reorgonize files in environment folder? | ImproperlyConfigured
items.body:
I am trying to use you application in my project but it raise error:
```
ImproperlyConfigured: settings.DATABASES is improperly configured.
Please supply the ENGINE value.
Check settings documentation for more details.
```

**P.S.** Database settings are correct. With next settings I can run project with `python manage.py runserver` command without any problem. Error happens when user try to go to any link of the project. It seems to me that I reorgonize `development.py` file (which inside environment folder) incorrect. Can you give me some advice, please? I tested right now and notice that if I set  `'components/database_developemnt.py'` in `base_settings `of `__init__.py` file, it works fine. But as you can see from the structure below I have 2 database settings file. One for development and one fore production.

I use:
```
Django 1.11
Python 2.7
```

**structure:**
```
project_name/settings/
    __init__.py
    components
        __init__.py
        common.py
        secret_key.py
        database_development.py
        database_production.py
    environments
        __init__.py
        development.py
        production.py
```

**__ init __.py:**
```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

from split_settings.tools import include
from os import environ

ENVIRONMENT = 'development' or 'production'

base_settings = [
    'components/common.py',  # Common settings which I use in development and in production
    'components/secret_key.py',  # Secret key of the project which generated by Django

    'environments/%s.py' % ENVIRONMENT,
]

include(*base_settings)
```
**database_development.py:**
```
DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.oracle',
        'NAME': 'NAME',
        'USER': 'USER',
        'PASSWORD': 'PASSWORD',
    }
}
```

**development.py:**
```
from split_settings.tools import include, optional

DEBUG = True

development_settings = [
    optional('components/database_development.py'),  # Database for development
    optional('components/logging.py'),  # Logging in developement
]

include(*development_settings)
```

items.title: duplicate dir name \split_settings
items.body:
it's not possible `<project_dir>/<project_dir>/split_settings/*.py`

`from split_settings.tools import include, optional` - not working in this case, 

Error:
```
from split_settings.tools import include
ImportError: No module named tools
```

bugfix is just rename dir to any other

items.title: Dynamic settings
items.body: Nice solution, but couldn't find best practice how to use settings from one component within another one. For example, we have `components\django.py` that uses some variables from `components\common.py`, is it safety to do an import? How you organizing it? I wasn't able to find such samples in tests.

items.title: Import from  one file to another
items.body:
I define some settings in One file
but I need to import into another 
how to do it?
for example base_dir

items.title: Follow the checklist
items.body: Just a quick review if everything is fine would be nice: http://djangoappschecklist.com/

items.title: OSError in case of different include places in code
items.body:
I have settings struct like:

```
project\
+    settings\
    +    components\
         __init__.py ← here is placed next code:
```

```python
# Base settings
include(
    'components/django.py',
    'components/rest.py',
    'components/channels.py',
    …
    optional('../settings_docker.py')
)

# if i place this import here it should have this path t be imported
# and it looks correct
if 'test' in sys.argv or 'test_coverage' in sys.argv:
    include(
        'components/tests.py',
    )

try:
    include(
        optional('../settings_local.py')
    )
except FileNotFoundError:
    pass

try:
    include(
        optional('../settings_local_ansible.py')
    )
except FileNotFoundError:
    pass

# but if i place this import here it should have this path t be imported
# and it looks not correct. 
# Here `include` function adds `../` on the front of import path somehow.
if 'test' in sys.argv or 'test_coverage' in sys.argv:
    include(
        'settings/components/tests.py',
    )
```

`try…except` blocks here to avoid error in case if symbolic link exists but target file not.

items.title: Add tox-travis
items.body:
Right now `travis` is broken. It does not pre-install `python3.5` and `python3.6`.
https://github.com/ryanhiebert/tox-travis

So the build fails. https://travis-ci.org/sobolevn/django-split-settings/jobs/223140753

items.title: Add tests for python3.6 and Django 1.11
items.body:
Since new `django` is released, we need to test the support. It should be fine.

And also add new `python` version to the tests. It should be also fine, but there's this annoying `travis` bug with new `python` version that they should be explicitly specified in the `python: ` block.

items.title: PyPI pages does not render rst correctly
items.body:
For some reason our page on PyPI looks broken. https://pypi.python.org/pypi/django-split-settings

`rst` is not rendered.
We should fix that.

items.title: Get rid of some __init__.py files in tests
items.body: `pytest` does not require `__init__.py` to be there. So it can be easily removed.

items.title: Change how the tests work
items.body:
There several improvements I really like to make:

- [x] replace coverage tool with http://pytest-cov.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
- [x] make `pytest` fixtures
- [x] restructure fixtures
- [x] remove old `coverage` tox target

items.title: Error with unicode module names on Python2
items.body:
I maintain a Django installation and want to migrate the settings (lots of `from X import *`) to _django-split-setings_. Seems everything went fine, but the tox test for Python 2.7 (the only tested version < 3) bailed on me with the following error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".tox/py27/bin/django-admin.py", line 5, in <module>
    management.execute_from_command_line()
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 353, in execute_from_command_line
    utility.execute()
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/management/__init__.py", line 302, in execute
    settings.INSTALLED_APPS
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/conf/__init__.py", line 55, in __getattr__
    self._setup(name)
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/conf/__init__.py", line 43, in _setup
    self._wrapped = Settings(settings_module)
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/conf/__init__.py", line 99, in __init__
    mod = importlib.import_module(self.SETTINGS_MODULE)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/importlib/__init__.py", line 37, in import_module
    __import__(name)
  File "/home/…/source/streambox/streambox/settings/test.py", line 19, in <module>
    scope=globals()
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/split_settings/tools.py", line 84, in include
    exec(compile(to_compile.read(), included_file, 'exec'), scope)
  File "/home/…/source/streambox/streambox/settings/components/base.py", line 147, in <module>
    scope=globals()
  File "/home/…/source/.tox/py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/split_settings/tools.py", line 90, in include
    module = types.ModuleType(module_name)
TypeError: module.__init__() argument 1 must be string, not unicode
```

This might be a result of `from __future__ import unicode_literals`. Any ideas how to handle this?

items.title: Issue with Python 3.5 and Django 1.6.11
items.body:
The build is failing for some reason. 
https://travis-ci.org/sobolevn/django-split-settings/jobs/92537954

It is now excluded from `travis` builds.

items.title: Import error
items.body:
I have experienced some very odd behaivor. 
File structure:
- settings
  - __ init__.py
  - first.py

In file __ init__.py:

```
include(
    'first.py',
    scope=locals()
)
```

In file first.py:

```
import os

class DevelopmentConfiguration(object):
    def test(self):
        # workaround: 
        # import os
        print os.path.join('root', 'subfolder')

test = DevelopmentConfiguration()
test.test()
```

This returns "NameError: global name 'os' is not defined".
Is it supposed to be like that? 
There is a workaround to specify function-level imports, but it is an ugly solution.

I am using Python 2.7.5 and django-split-settings==0.1.1

items.title: The publication of the new version in the repository PyPi.
items.body:
When?
These are important improvements in the code that bring compatibility with Python 3.

items.title: ImproperlyConfigured at XXX | settings does not seem to load
items.body:
Hi,

first of all, thank you for this app, it seems great. However, I can't get it to work !

I followed the docs and informations from this [blog entry](http://www.2general.com/blog/2013/05/17/django_settings_split.html) but on every request, I get the following error : 

```
ImproperlyConfigured at /

Put 'django.contrib.contenttypes' in your INSTALLED_APPS setting in order to use the admin application.
```

If I remove `admin.site.urls` from my urls.py, i get this : 

```
ImproperlyConfigured at /

settings.DATABASES is improperly configured. Please supply the ENGINE value. Check settings documentation for more details.
```

If I understand correctly, my settings are not loaded at all. But :
- `python manage.py validate` does not raise any error. My settings seems to load, as shown by some print statements i've put in settings files
- on django error debug page, when I scroll down, I can see that my settings values are listed and correct (even values that are considered as missing by error text)

Here is my folder structure (kii is the name of my project) :
kii
├── settings
│   ├── components
│   │   ├── apps_settings.py
│   │   ├── base_settings.py
│   │   ├── kii_settings.py
│   │   └── locale_settings.py
│   ├── dev.py
│   ├── **init**.py

Here is content of **init** and dev files :
# settings/**init**.py

```
from split_settings.tools import optional, include
include(
    'components/kii_settings.py',
    'components/base_settings.py',
    'components/apps_settings.py',
    'components/locale_settings.py',
    'dev.py',
    scope=locals()
)
```
# settings/dev.py

```
import os
print('local_settings loaded')
DEBUG = True
TEMPLATE_DEBUG = DEBUG

ADMINS += (
# ('Your Name', 'your_email@example.com'),
)

DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.mysql', # Add 'postgresql_psycopg2', 'mysql', 'sqlite3' or 'oracle'.
        'NAME': 'XXXX',                      # Or path to database file if using sqlite3.
        # The following settings are not used with sqlite3:
        'USER': 'root',
        'PASSWORD': 'XXXX',
        'HOST': '',                      # Empty for localhost through domain sockets or '127.0.0.1' for localhost through TCP.
        'PORT': '',                      # Set to empty string for default.
        'OPTIONS': {
        "init_command": "SET storage_engine=MyISAM",
        } 

        }
        }
ALLOWED_HOSTS=[]
MEDIA_ROOT = os.path.join(PROJECT_PATH, "media")

INSTALLED_APPS += (
    'debug_toolbar',
) 

MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES = (    
    'debug_toolbar.middleware.DebugToolbarMiddleware',
)

DEBUG_TOOLBAR_CONFIG= { "INTERCEPT_REDIRECTS":False}
```

And finally, the whole error stacktrace :

```
Environment:


Request Method: GET
Request URL: http://127.0.0.1:8000/

Django Version: 1.5.5
Python Version: 2.7.3
Installed Applications:
('django.contrib.auth',
'django.contrib.contenttypes',

'django.contrib.sites',

'debug_toolbar')
Installed Middleware:
('debug_toolbar.middleware.DebugToolbarMiddleware',)


Traceback:
File "/home/eliotberriot/Envs/kii/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py" in get_response
92.                     response = middleware_method(request)
File "/home/eliotberriot/Envs/kii/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/utils/importlib.py" in import_module
35.     __import__(name)
File "/home/eliotberriot/kii/kii/urls.py" in <module>
23.     url(r'^admin/', include(admin.site.urls)),  
File "/home/eliotberriot/Envs/kii/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/contrib/admin/sites.py" in urls
257.         return self.get_urls(), self.app_name, self.name
File "/home/eliotberriot/Envs/kii/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/contrib/admin/sites.py" in get_urls
215.             self.check_dependencies()
File "/home/eliotberriot/Envs/kii/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/contrib/admin/sites.py" in check_dependencies
165.             raise ImproperlyConfigured("Put 'django.contrib.contenttypes' in "

Exception Type: ImproperlyConfigured at /
Exception Value: Put 'django.contrib.contenttypes' in your INSTALLED_APPS setting in order to use the admin application.
```

Am I missing something obvious ? Thank you for your time and your help, just tell me if you need more informations.

items.title: Impossible to run gunicorn with django-split-settings
items.body:
Running the command :

python manage.py run_gunicorn

Produces the following stack trace:

``` python
2013-08-21 13:28:17 [8477] [INFO] Starting gunicorn 0.17.4
Starting gunicorn 0.17.4
2013-08-21 13:28:17 [8477] [INFO] Listening at: http://0.0.0.0:7777 (8477)
Listening at: http://0.0.0.0:7777 (8477)
2013-08-21 13:28:17 [8477] [INFO] Using worker: sync
Using worker: sync
2013-08-21 13:28:17 [8486] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 8486
Booting worker with pid: 8486
2013-08-21 13:28:17 [8486] [ERROR] Exception in worker process:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/arbiter.py", line 473, in spawn_worker
    worker.init_process()
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/workers/base.py", line 100, in init_process
    self.wsgi = self.app.wsgi()
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/app/base.py", line 106, in wsgi
    self.callable = self.load()
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/app/djangoapp.py", line 134, in load
    return mod.make_command_wsgi_application(self.admin_media_path)
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/app/django_wsgi.py", line 113, in make_command_wsgi_application
    reload_django_settings()
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gunicorn/app/django_wsgi.py", line 54, in reload_django_settings
    reload(mod)
  File "/home/myhome/projects/myvirtualenv/myproject/settings/production.py", line 31, in <module>
    scope=locals()
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/split_settings/tools.py", line 40, in include
    confpath = os.path.dirname(including_file)
  File "/home/myhome/.virtualenvs/myvirtualenv/lib/python2.7/posixpath.py", line 120, in dirname
    i = p.rfind('/') + 1
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'rfind'

```

locals()['**included_file**'] exists but is set to None

A quick fix could be to replace the line (in tools.py):

```
including_file = scope.get('__included_file__', scope['__file__'])
```

by

```
including_file = scope.get('__included_file__') or scope['__file__']
```
